SENT.plain: While the intraluminal thread technique to induce middle cerebral artery occlusion is widely used in animal models of focal cerebral ischemia, it has several drawbacks
The present study describes a new technique involving transfemoral selective intraluminal wiring, and evaluates its technical feasibility, effectiveness, and safety

Twenty-four Wistar rats were used in this work: two for a vascular anatomy study and 22 subjected to middle cerebral artery occlusion for 1 h by our new transfemoral selective "intraluminal wiring" technique
After 24 h of reperfusion, the animals were evaluated neurologically, and then were sacrificed

Macroscopic, histological (2,3,5-triphenyltetrazolium chloride (TTC), hematoxylin-eosin and TUNEL), and biochemical (DNA fragmentation and caspase-3 activity) studies were performed to assess the extent of brain damage produced by focal ischemia
Technical success was obtained in all 22 animals
Signs of focal ischemia and reperfusion, such as necrosis and apoptosis, were detected in the middle cerebral artery territory
No subarachnoid hemorrhage was noticed in any animal
Transfemoral selective intraluminal wiring appears to be a reliable, safe, and minimally invasive technique to induce transient focal cerebral ischemia in rats
